[John Piper] "Not only is all your affliction momentary,
not only is all your affliction light
in comparison to eternity and the glory there,
but all of it is totally meaningful.
Every millisecond of your pain
from the fallen nature or fallen man,
every millisecond of your misery in the path of obedience
is producing a peculiar glory you will get because of that.
I don't care if it was cancer or criticism.
I don't care if it was slander or sickness.
It wasn't meaningless.
It's doing something! It's not meaningless.
Of course you can't see what it's doing.

When your mom dies, when your kid dies,
when you've got cancer at 40,
when a car careens into the sidewalk and takes her out,

Therefore, therefore, do not lose heart.
But take these truths and day by day focus on them.
Preach them to yourself every morning.
Get alone with God and preach his word into your mind

comments.text:
"And behold, the corpse was carried to the burial; we went and returned 
without tears. For neither in those prayers which we poured forth unto 
Thee, when the Sacrifice of our ransom was offered for her, when now the 
corpse was by the grave`s side, as the manner there is, previous to its 
being laid therein, did I weep even during those prayers; yet was I the 
whole day in secret heavily sad, and with troubled mind prayed Thee, as I 
could, to heal my sorrow, yet Thou didst not; impressing, I believe, upon 
my memory by this one instance, how strong is the bond of all habit, even 
upon a soul, which now feeds upon no deceiving Word. It seemed also good to 
me to go and bathe, having heard that the bath had its name (balneum) from 
the Greek Bahavelov, for that it drives sadness from the mind. And this 
also I confess unto Thy mercy, Father of the fatherless, that I bathed, and 
was the same as before I bathed. For the bitterness of sorrow could not 
exude out of my heart. Then I slept, and woke up again, and found my grief 
not a little softened; and as I was alone in my bed, I remembered those 
true verses of Thy Ambrose. For Thou art the 

"Maker of all, the Lord, 
And Ruler of the height, 
Who, robing day in light, hast poured 
Soft slumbers o`er the night, 

"That to our limbs the power 
Of toil may be renew`d, 
And hearts be rais`d that sink and cower, 
And sorrows be subdu`d.""

-Augustine (on grieving the death of his mother)﻿

comments.text:
Suffering can be hard, awful. But rather than focus primarily on me and the 
benefits we gain as Christians through suffering, our focus ought to be 
trained on Christ and His cross.  God has architected a world where 
everyone will, at some point, suffer.  He did this so that His name would 
be famous through Christ, who suffered in the place of those who hated Him.

Suffering, then, finds its very meaning in the shed blood of the 
cross-bearing God, who invites us to carry about in our physical bodies the 
death of Jesus (2 Cor. 4:10).﻿

There is no "problem" with Christianity.  We all struggle at different 
points to live it out, speak in truth, and interpret his Word through our 
walk in sanctification  led by the Spirit.  Our world is fallen and broken, 
and yes, sin is a real defining problem, however, God is not to blame for 
that.  He is holy and worthy of our worship.  He is worthy of a genuine 
relationship and to be praised forever through his Son Jesus.  Most of the 
problem from "Christianity" is that anyone can claim to be a Christian, but 
who goes around claiming to be a follower of Christ?  Who follows his 
commands?  But this song leads to powerful surrender and humility leading 
to worship of our Great High Priest.  God Bless!﻿

comments.text:
"Problem with Christianity"? Is a discussion over the truth of scripture 
cause people to ignore truth? I say it sways the opinion of one no more 
than two atheists who argue over philosophy causes the layperson to ignore 
the truth-claims of a materialistic worldview. 

No, I think it honors God when we take His word seriously. It means we take 
truth seriously. That we take HIM seriously. Truth is not relative, and as 
Christians we must seek to understand that truth. 

Instead of a lack of discussion, we should, rather, have our disagreements 
gilded with grace. We may disagree, but we must do so with care for the 
soul we find error in, knowing that we ourselves are not, and will never 
be, perfect in our theology.

comments.text:
Emily,
If you read my comments above you will understand that I agree with you. 
 My point is that some try to make sickness or trouble an issue of sin and 
while that's sometimes true it is not for many.  We read again and again of 
saints in the Bible who suffered greatly, including our Savior, Jesus, and 
yet somehow folks come away like Job's friends did and blame the sufferer 
for their pain.  We live in a sin-cursed world and we are told the rain 
falls on the just and the unjust.  

And trust me, I do focus on the grander scheme.  I owe Him my life, He 
promises me eternal life.  It doesn't get any better than that.
comments.author: A Cashman

comments.text:
Unfortunately you have chosen to do what Job's friends did - punch him when 
he was down.  Again, folks, this is a song about anguish and suffering.  I 
do not like how to basically say, "If you obey and are good you will avoid 
trouble."  Now, that my friend is a lie.  We are told that the rain falls 
on the just and the unjust and while I will not disagree that folks can 
definitely bring trouble upon themselves with sin - you make any trouble 
one encounters an issue of sin.  I love Jesus, have obeyed, but am 
chronically ill with Lyme Disease and the various coinfections that come 
with it.  It got it from my husband who got a tick bite out in the woods. 
 I did nothing to deserve this illness other than be a faithful wife.  I 
cling to Christ, I believe He heals, I pray for healing, and yet I am sick. 
 You are making the sad mistake that Job's friends made when he was going 
through trials and in the end, it was he who had to pray for his friends 
who thought they were righteous.
comments.author: A Cashman

comments.text:
+Mambochief
Mambochief,

You are correct in the distinction between the meaning of "cause" or 
"allow;" however, in the middle of a trial they can seem very similar. 
 Remember that this is an artistic song not a book on doctrine.  I listened 
to the song 2 more times and then the video they did on the inspiration of 
the song to make sure I was clear before I wrote anymore.  

David, a man after God's heart, wrote many of the Psalms and even he 
stated, "Why, O LORD, do you stand far off?"  Was God far off?  No.  And 
yet David in his anguish felt as if God were far off.  And while we know 
that "Every good and perfect gift is from above..." (James 1:17) it can 
feel often times quite the reverse down here.  I don't read David's words 
and doubt God.  I read them and think, "Wow, I'm not alone!  David, a man 
after God's own heart, even felt this way!  

I think the "test" of the sincerity of this song is the rest of what he 
sings.... "yet will I serve thee... still I worship thee... sing a song to 
the One who is all I need."  Obviously this person isn't blaming a 
"vengeful God who takes."  He sings and uses words from Job because that is 
how he (his mother) felt.  He's saying that whatever happens, he's going to 
praise the name of the Lord.  We are listening to the cry of a woman (the 
songwriter's mother) who just lost her husband.  She beat on his dead chest 
with her fists as she was hyperventilating.  We are hearing the words of a 
broken, anguished woman.  I was angry with my brother for drowning.  Is 
that biblically accurate?  Of course not!  But it's what I felt for a while!

When the preacher comes in the song his message it is not "a vengeful God 
who takes," but rather he admonishes us to not look upon what is seen and 
say, "it is meaningless," but to not lose heart and know that every 
affliction has meaning whether it's cancer, slander, or sickness and to 
"preach these truths to ourselves."

Songs, like stories are for many purposes.  Some are for doctrine but 
others help us understand the human condition.  This song expressed what I 
have often felt while suffering and frankly, I'm thankful he put into words 
things what many have gone through and felt.  I can relate.  This helps and 
is cathartic for me.  I pray, Mambochief, that you have grace enough to 
allow others to express what they are feeling, while still serving the King 
of Kings in obedience.
comments.author: A Cashman

comments.text:
"Allow" or "Cause" are not semantic trivialities friend...not by a long 
shot. They are the difference between  and victim and perpetrator. When 
Paul was harming the early Church, throwing them into prison and complicit 
in their death as in Stephen, when Jesus met him on the road to Damascus, 
He didn't say it was the Father that was ruining, slaying and taking from 
the early church. He approached the perpetrator and ask Saul why are you 
persecuting me? Because Christ who is God identified Himself not with the 
perpetrator and persecutor but with the persecuted. God is not an abusive 
parent or abusive spouse who beats the snot out of his 'loved ones' and 
demands they respond with the sweetness that becomes them well.

Jesus is the LOGOS of God, meaning all the Father wanted to say about 
Himself was exhibited in the son. You look at how Jesus dealt with people 
and that was an exhibition of the Father's heart...when they were hungry he 
fed them, when they were cast out(leper, woman with the issue of blood, 
prostitute with the alabaster jar, the woman caught in adultery, the woman 
at the well, Zaccheus) Jesus showed them acceptance, love and compassion. 
That was the Father's heart. The demoniac in Gadarenes, he delivered, the 
woman with the spirit of infirmity he told her you are loosed from your 
infirmity, that was the Father's heart on display. He is not in the 
business slaying, taking from or ruining His children...What about Jesus' 
death you ask me? Jesus' suffering and death was a ransom paid for the 
redemption of humanity. A one time event that took place in a space of less 
than 24 hours with resurrection 3 days later, never more to die.

When the Pharisees attacked Christ's ministry, He said they are of their 
father the Devil, he never said, the Father is doing this to me. He knew 
who his enemy was and who is the real abuser of our species. You don't have 
to be sorry about what I've seen or have been through. i just shared that 
to point out point out that bad things happen because we live a fallen 
world but let us never act as if God is the perpetrator of man's death, 
plunder and ruin. The old saints used to sing what a friend we have in 
Jesus, all our sins and griefs to bear...the new saints engage in poetic 
however soulish/country song type 'worship' that comes across as a weird 
cross between spiritual masochism and the Stockholm Syndrome. It is the 
beautiful and sentimental crooning of the well-fed.
comments.author: Mambochief

comments.text:
Dearest Mambochief,
I am so sorry for what you have seen and survived.  Only the grace of God 
can heal what you've been through.  And I pray my friend that Jesus would 
comfort you in such a marvelous way that you have spill over for others who 
need it.  And yes you are right in that God comes to give life and 
abundantly!   If we truly believe God is the Maker and Creator and Messiah, 
we will also agree that nothing happens outside His perfect will.  So what 
if bad things happen?  Did He not know about that?  Yes He did and He 
allowed it for whatever reason.  It's not for me to know it's for me to 
obey.  That's why we are called "children of God."  So we are debating over 
semantics, particularly over the words "allow or cause."  Without 
personally knowing the beliefs of these singers, from the lead singer's 
testimony of how he came to write the song, I believe he as I believe that 
whatever havoc the enemy wants to do in our lives has to be cleared by our 
heavenly Father - so in essence He's in on it as He allowed it. We are told 
by Paul to be thankful in all circumstances whether in need or with plenty. 
 God has a divine plan and pain and suffering are a part of that plan to 
refine us.
comments.author: A Cashman

comments.text:

very 3 things Jesus in John 10:10 says the thief comes to do...steal(take 
from you) to kill (slay you) and to destroy(ruin you).....never was that 
every attributed to the Father. The Lord did not slay Job...which is where 
that portion of the song is taken. Job survived his trial where the 
enemy...not God got a shot at stealing killing and destroying. I am a child 
of war....born in war, have seen death all around me...here's my 
resume...My grandmother(mom's mom) my favorite uncle(uncle David) and my 
cousin were brutally killed on the same day, my nana was literally cut in 
two) Not once did I ever think God did it. It was clear whose 'ministry' 
that was. I would sing this song, though the enemy slay me, yet will I 
praise your name, though he take from me, still I'll bless your name, 
though he ruin me...etc...for in the worst of my trials there has been no 
confusion about what my Father(take a moment to see what that might mean)

comments.text:
His will for us is Rio grow closer to him, and to bring others closer to 
him. If you read Job, you will see that God did not bring him his 
suffering; it was from Satan, but God permitted it. Why did he permit it? 
Because he knew what was on the other side! Not only Job, but also his 
friends, were brought closer to God through Job's suffering. And a wrong 
belief that they espoused, that only those who were sinners suffered, was 
dispelled. Job became more blessed after his suffering, because he 
suffered. What God does is to bring great things from our pain, and 
blessings from our loss. "And we know that in all things God works for the 
good of those who love him, who are called according to his purpose." 
(Romans 8:28). He also said, "In this world you will have trouble, but take 
heart; I have overcome the world." And, "No servant is greater than his 
master." Jesus suffered terribly while he was here. Should I, then, expect 
a trouble free life, if my master suffered?
comments.author: Lisa Drouillard

comments.text:
Read Job. These words are straight from Jobs mouth. Let me ask you this: 
Does God put us through trials and tribulations to refine us as gold as the 
Bible says? If you say yes, you believe God has ordained that circumstance. 
9/10 times that circumstance is not fun because some kind of "bad thing" 
had to happen to "break us" to put us in a position where God can use us. 
Once again, back to Job, who does Job attribute the taking of his children 
to? God. "the Lord gives, and the Lord takes away." not "the devil takes 
away". Why? Because God is in control of the entire situation, as we see 
the Devil cannot even move against God's own without permission. God ruins 
us, so that he may build us back, better and stronger.
comments.author: Conservative Connection

comments.text:
This song is based on Job.  It is a clear picture of the sovereignty of God 
even over Satan.  Yes Satan ravishes Job's life but it is clearly only 
because the Lord in His wisdom has allowed it.  Job acknowledges that God 
is ultimately in charge of the whole affair when he says "the Lord has 
given and the Lord has taken away, blessed be the name of the Lord".  And 
scripture says in all of this Job accused God of no wrong.  Job 13:15 says 
"though he slay me, I will hope in him".   Job is trusting in God and the 
"he" that slays is this very same God that he is trusting in.  It is a 
testament to the trust Job places in the God he follows that if God in His 
wisdom sees it is best to slay Job in this life Job's heart will hope in 
him confident that he will redeem even this slaying for his good.  It is a 
difficult thing for our fallen finite hearts to understand that a 
sovereign, holy, loving God who is free of sin and never violates His 
holiness does allow for suffering in this broken world.  It is broken 
because of our sin and we suffer greatly under the curse, but for the 
Christian, bought by the blood of Christ, EVERYTHING now works for our good 
and God's glory.  There is no dualism at play in the life of the Christian 
because even our sin, even our failures, and the evidences of the curse 
that remain in us are redeemed for our good and His glory.  EVERYTHING! 
 This is made so clear throughout scripture.  The prosperity gospel has 
clouded the understanding of many and the same folly that led Job's 
"counselors" to give their poor advice has led Christians to miss the 
richness of knowing that in suffering, disease, loss, failure, falling etc 
there is the cross... redeeming all of it for our good and the praise of 
God.  I sin but as a Christian that sin has already been dealt with and 
adequate justice meted out such that even my mistakes and sins are being 
used by God to work good for me and achieve His own glory through it.  Do 
we then sin that grace might much more abound... no scripture says... and 
yet even in our great sinning grace does abound for the regenerate heart 
that is truly humbled before the cross.
comments.author: Todd Personett
